I'm working to apply for a grant from unearthodox, here's some of their content: From Reframing to Reimagining. Together.
In 2024, as part of the Regenerative Futures programme, Unearthodox embarked on a year of deep listening, questioning, and unravelling a multitude of regenerative perspectives from around the globe. 
This was not just a research initiative. It was a collective act of emergence. We engaged with over 500 voices - from artists, Indigenous knowledge holders, conservationists, to foresight practitioners, economists, farmers, activists, and systems thinkers - coming from institutes, NGOs, and academia. Together, we surfaced answers to the question “What does regeneration mean?”
Learn more about the programme activities
By creating multiple access points for engagement - storytelling, art, music, poetry, science, and immersive dialogue - we enabled more voices to contribute beyond traditional expert-led processes and mainstream narratives.
What follows are the echoes of this reframing year, a chorus of tensions, lived experiences, and invitations. Enter gingerly. Let your thoughts linger. Allow a piece of work to both disturb and delight you. Follow the stories that resonate. Add your own.
What does regeneration mean?
From Reframing to Reimagining
“As I have learned from Elders, Youth and other knowledge keepers we've had the opportunity to work with on the Reconnection Vision, regeneration means the restoration of healthy relationships - with all parts of ourselves, with each other, with the land.”
Jodi Gustafson, referencing the Reconnection Vision

“In my delta village, decay and rebirth are one. The rotting stalk feeds the next crop. That is regeneration.”
Abirami R, Cycles of Hope

"Regeneration is the spark that moves us from chaos to creativity — from loss to living story."
 Sarah Queblatin, Insight Piece

“Regeneration to me is learning to see the more-than-human world as kin, not resource.”
Lauren Saunders, Cycles of Hope 

“Regeneration is not just practice but stewardship — a commitment to tend what was harmed, so life can return in many forms.”
Myra Colis, Cycles of Hope 

“We breathe the breath of the trees,  regeneration is knowing that each breath binds us to all life.”
Arowah Cleaver, Regeneration: A Meditation 

“Regeneration is a verb — we imagine otherwise, so we can act otherwise.”
Rahel Könen, Cycles of Hope

"Regeneration is not only practice — it is ancient wisdom that is inherent in nature and within us."
Lua Couto, Insight Piece

“Regeneration is the default mode of life. One species, human beings, has forgotten it.”
Paul Hawken, Exploratory Call

"Regeneration is about learning to live in a healthy symbiosis with nature — restoring what makes life possible."
Sumru Ramsey, Insight Piece

"Regeneration asks us to shift from industrial logic to a holistic socio-ecological systems logic — seeing humans and nature as one interdependent whole."
Nadja Skaljic, Insight Piece

The Core Dimensions of Regeneration

New Relationships
“What if nature held the board seat instead of me?” - Nadja Skaljic

Regeneration invites us to centre harmony where extraction has been the norm. From community managed gardens to boardrooms where people turn into guardians of nature, regeneration compels us to see humans not as separate from nature, but as part of the living we of life on Earth. 


Cycles of Life

Indigenous & Ancestral Wisdom

Reimagining Societies and Systems: to rethink societal structures to align with life

Beyond Sustainability
What Regeneration should not be…
Our conversations also uncovered deep concerns, not about regeneration as a concept, but about what it might become if not rooted in the principles and values.

Nothing but just another buzzword
There is a genuine apprehension that regeneration may be diluted, vague, overused - a term used to greenwash and continue business as usual, with no real systems change behind it when regeneration is treated as nothing more than a marketing tool for branding as green, its potential for deep systemic change is diluted.

"Regen-washing (and all alternatives to regenerative) is underway in many endeavours. Unseen and unintended." Graham Boyd, Exploratory Calls


Cultural appropriation

Superficial uses to secure funding

Misunderstanding & dilution

New ways of extraction and exploitation
The ‘Tensions’ Shaping Regenerative Thinking
Our year-long inquiry into the concept of regeneration also surfaced “tensions” -  not barriers that need instant fixing, but paradoxes that shape how regenerative practices are executed. These tensions are not new; they echo the polarities and dilemmas that many in the systems thinking field continue to grapple with today. Polarities can be generative when acknowledged. Many innovations arise not by resolving a polarity, but by living with it. It is often in the space between opposites that new patterns, practices, and possibilities emerge.

Tensions remind us that regeneration is not always a linear process but a living practice of navigating contradictions. Here are eight of these tensions that we are focusing on.

Holding these tensions, for Unearthodox, means staying aware of how a regenerative idea can respond to both ends of the polarity.
So, what are the principles for regenerative practice?
Relationality: Honour interdependence - human and more-than-human kinship.

Plurality: Hold diverse ways of knowing. Resist linear approaches.

Justice: Root regeneration in equity and decolonisation. 

Openness over control: Value emergence as a natural part of the process

Care over extraction: Design that nourishes, not depletes.

Conclusion
To sum up, what we have learnt is that regeneration is not something we just sustain, it is what we remember, embody and practice daily for life to flourish.

**Regenerative Vision - How does your idea weave relationships between people, place, planet and time? (200 words max)**

Extractive funding creates extractive relationships with nature. When teams chase investor returns, they can't pursue work that regenerates slowly—soil restoration, ecosystem revival, circular systems that give back more than they take.

Our solidarity pool breaks that pattern. By pooling revenue across seasons and sectors—agriculture peaks in summer, education in fall-spring, psychology services off-season—we create stability that mirrors natural cycles rather than fighting them. Teams can plan multi-year ecological work instead of quarterly results.

The interconnection is direct: financial resilience enables ecological resilience. Mary Claire's circular economy turns agricultural waste into menstrual products, but she can't invest in better production or expand to more communities without stable income. Salaam's waste management innovation using IoT sensors was advised not to even register in Palestine's collapsed economy. These aren't just social enterprises—they're ecological interventions blocked by financial instability.

Solidarity finance is itself regenerative: it gives back more than it takes, builds relationships instead of extracting value, operates on gift culture rather than debt. We're proving that regenerating economies enables regenerating ecosystems—urgent climate needs met through long-term community infrastructure, not short-term investor timelines.

**Words: 198**

---

**Community-Rooted Practice - How is your idea grounded in lived experiences and place-based knowledge? (200 words max)**

I'm Kurdish-Iraqi-American, raised in Muslim diaspora where my closest friends were Syrian, Palestinian, Lebanese. These conflicts aren't "over there"—they're home. I've worked alongside these 1,011 entrepreneurs for 10 years, through Lebanon's collapse, Beirut's explosion, Gaza's siege.

The solidarity pool draws directly on traditional models our communities already know: African tontines, stokvels, Middle Eastern chamas, ROSCAs. We're not importing foreign solutions—we're adapting centuries-old practices that sustained villages through crisis.

We're accountable to the teams themselves. I've called 22 entrepreneurs asking: what do you actually need? Revenue pooling emerged from their lived experience of choppy income, not our assumptions. They're co-designing governance—contribution rates, withdrawal rules, conflict resolution. Democratic process, not top-down design.

Place-based knowledge matters: agriculture teams know their seasons, education teams know school cycles, psychology teams know cultural trauma patterns. The pool works because it respects these rhythms instead of forcing "scalability."

We give back by staying. Other accelerators run programs and leave. We're building persistent infrastructure—our platform, library, assessment tools are all open-access. If the pool works, governance transfers to teams. They own it.

Global collaboration happens through shared learning, but local autonomy stays protected.

**Words: 200**

---

**Innovation and Imagination - How does your idea look beyond systems of harm and challenge dominant paradigms? (200 words max)**

The dominant paradigm is "accelerator to investor pipeline": train entrepreneurs, connect them to capital, measure success by scale and exit. This imported venture capital logic into development, making enterprises serving poor communities or pursuing ecological restoration "uninvestable."

We're challenging the pipeline itself. What if there's no exit? What if horizontal federation replaces vertical scale? What if gift-anchored finance replaces return-seeking investment?

Our innovation is material, not just informational. Most alumni networks share job postings and advice. We're sharing resources—actual money pooled collectively. That's fundamentally different.

We're also challenging who decides. Traditional finance: investors evaluate entrepreneurs and decide who gets funded based on projected returns. Solidarity pool: entrepreneurs evaluate their own needs collectively and decide together how resources flow. Power shifts horizontally.

This encourages new ways of relating to resources. Instead of "my revenue vs. your revenue" (competition for scarce funding), it's "our collective stability" (cooperation for shared resilience). Instead of "scale or die," it's "sustain and deepen."

Technology serves relationships: our platform facilitates peer learning, democratic governance, and transparent pooling. It doesn't replace human connection—it enables coordination across 16 countries while maintaining trust built through our programs.

The vision: regenerative economies deserve regenerative finance.

**Words: 200**

---

**Equity and Inclusion - How does your idea center justice and equity for communities and all living systems? (200 words max)**

Power currently sits with investors and donors who decide which enterprises get funded. Our solidarity pool shifts power to entrepreneurs themselves—teams decide collectively how resources flow, what contribution rates are fair, who can withdraw when.

This addresses structural inequity: enterprises led by women, refugees, people in conflict zones, those serving marginalized communities are deemed "too risky" or "unscalable" by traditional investors. Mary Claire in Cameroon, Sumayya in Gaza, Clara in Lebanon—all doing critical work but locked out of growth capital because their margins are thin and their contexts are "unstable."

We're led by people from these communities. I'm Kurdish-Iraqi-American working in MENA/Africa for 10 years. Our teams are 61% women-led (Lebanon), 55% women-led (Palestine), 90% women-led (HerMeNow). Many are refugees or people who stayed when others left.

We're challenging colonial patterns by building on Indigenous solidarity finance models, not importing Western VC logic. Democratic governance means no top-down control. Gift culture means no debt traps.

We avoid exploitation by prioritizing team stability over investor returns. If there's surplus, teams decide collectively whether to reinvest, distribute, or invite supporters to share. No one extracts value without community consent.

Living systems benefit when teams can pursue long-term ecological work.

**Words: 200**

**Capacity and Adaptability - How ready are you to engage in an 8-month collective learning process? (200 words max)**

We have infrastructure: 10 years of operations, 1,011 entrepreneur alumni, functioning platform with assessment tools and library, team across Lebanon and beyond. We've survived multiple crises by adapting—moved fully online during COVID, diversified operations to Dubai when Lebanon collapsed, built wellbeing practices into team culture.

We also have humility: I'm not pitching a perfect solution. I'm inviting co-creation. When I talk to teams, I share what we don't know—how should contribution rates work? What's fair withdrawal? How do we handle edge cases? That vulnerability builds trust.

We're organized to move forward while adapting: we have a community manager role planned, clear activities (data collection, pilot selection, governance design, testing, documentation), but the specifics will emerge from team conversations and learning.

Support we need: connections to cooperative federations and community wealth-building organizations doing similar work globally. Expertise in democratic governance at distance. Diaspora investors interested in gift-anchored finance. Other regenerative networks to share learnings with.

We demonstrate openness through action: all 22 teams I called were enthusiastic about being co-designers and future mentors. We're building this together, learning what creates stability for regenerative work, and sharing everything we learn publicly.

We're ready to be challenged and changed.

**Community Localism & Global Networks:** We're piloting across 16 countries digitally, which risks losing place-based specificity. Our approach: teams maintain complete autonomy over their local work while accessing transregional pooled resources. The governance is democratic but distributed—not centralized control from headquarters.

**Decolonisation & Institutional Constraints:** We need legal structures and banking systems designed by colonial powers to move money. Our response: we're drawing explicitly on pre-colonial solidarity finance models (tontines, chamas, ROSCAs) to contest the narrative that "professional investment" is the only way. We're also exploring how gift-anchored finance—where returns are optional and community-prioritized—challenges extractive institutional norms from within.

**Urgency & Deep Time:** Climate teams need funding now, but regenerative work requires multi-year commitments. The pool addresses both: immediate revenue stability (urgent) enables long-term ecological planning (deep time). Teams aren't choosing between survival this month and restoration over years—the pool provides both.

The solidarity model itself navigates urgency/deep-time: quick mutual aid when someone needs it, long-term collective resilience as the pool grows and governance deepens.

**Idea Title:**
Solidarity Revenue Pool: Regenerative Finance for Climate and Social Enterprises

---

**Executive Summary (200 words max):**

After 10 years supporting 1,011 social entrepreneurs across 16 countries, we've learned that short-term accelerators don't solve the funding gap. Teams doing critical climate work—circular economy in Cameroon, waste management in Palestine, trauma-safe media in Gaza—can't pursue long-term ecological restoration when they're working second jobs to survive.

We're piloting a solidarity revenue pool with 5-10 proven teams, drawing on traditional African and Middle Eastern mutual aid models (ROSCAs, tontines, chamas). Teams contribute small percentages during high-revenue months and withdraw during lean ones, creating collective stability without extractive funding.

This addresses a systemic problem: impact investing models imported from venture capital don't fund enterprises serving poor communities or pursuing ecological restoration with thin margins. The "wrong shape" for investors means meaningful climate work gets abandoned.

We've talked with 22 teams who are co-designing governance, contribution rates, and withdrawal rules democratically. Over 8 months, we'll test the pool, document what creates stability, and prove that gift-anchored finance can sustain regenerative work. If successful, we create a replicable model where community resilience replaces dependence on external funding that disappears when priorities shift.

**What are the gaps in the system(s)? (200 words max):**

The impact investing system is structurally extractive. It imports venture capital logic—scale, returns, exits—into development work, creating a gap: enterprises serving fundamental needs of poor communities with thin margins don't generate investor returns. Research from Mulago Foundation confirms this. So meaningful work gets abandoned despite impact.

Accelerators train entrepreneurs then push them toward an investor pipeline that was never designed to fund their work. The result: teams doing climate restoration, circular economy, community health can't sustain themselves. They work second jobs, hire unstably, lose institutional knowledge, burn out.

The gap is infrastructure. After the 3-6 month program, there's nothing. No persistent support, no community resources, no alternative to chasing investors or grants that disappear when donor priorities shift.

This creates a second gap: teams can't do long-term ecological restoration when they're in financial survival mode. Regenerating ecosystems requires stability. But the funding system demands quick scale and measurable ROI, which ecological work rarely provides on those timelines.

What's missing: community-based financial infrastructure that operates on solidarity rather than extraction, that values cultural embeddedness over "scalability," that enables teams to sustain work that actually regenerates communities and ecosystems.

**Words: 198**

**What opportunities and assets exist? (200 words max):**

We have a 10-year track record supporting 1,011 entrepreneurs across 16 countries through multiple crises—Lebanon's collapse, Beirut explosion, Gaza war. Our teams already show up for each other: after Beirut, they used WhatsApp to share contacts, boost marketing, offer support. ACSI4 alumni just self-organized a meetup post-program. Keren launched a joint venture with someone from her cohort.

Traditional solidarity finance models—African tontines, stokvels, Middle Eastern chamas, Asian ROSCAs—have sustained communities for centuries. They prove that pooling resources for mutual aid works at village scale with in-person trust.

Our Green Catalyst and HerMeNow programs already focus on climate enterprises: circular economy, waste management, sustainable agriculture, nature-based tourism. These teams exist, generate revenue, and serve communities—they just need stability.

The asset is trust. I've talked with 22 teams about co-designing this pool, and all were enthusiastic—not just as participants but as co-designers and future mentors. They want community infrastructure, not more pitch practice.

Cooperative movements like Mondragon prove horizontal federation works globally. We're building on centuries of solidarity finance, adapting it to digital-first, transregional social enterprises that don't fit investor models.

**Words: 199**

**If your idea unfolds as envisioned, what would it look like? (200 words max):**

Teams stop abandoning regenerative work because they can't predict next month's income. Clara expands her ADHD education program into schools. Sumayya continues trauma-safe media and support circles in Gaza. Mary Claire's circular economy project scales without conforming to investor growth expectations. Salaam's waste management innovation actually launches instead of shutting down before registration.

Entrepreneurs work full-time on their missions instead of side jobs. They hire stably, build institutional knowledge, plan multi-year ecological restoration projects. Revenue volatility no longer forces short-term thinking.

The pool itself becomes self-governing: teams decide contribution rates, withdrawal rules, conflict resolution democratically. Bloom becomes a member, not the administrator. Power shifts from external funders to entrepreneurs.

Other networks replicate the model. Solidarity finance infrastructure spreads across ecosystems of social enterprises globally. The "accelerator to investor pipeline" is no longer the only path—there's an alternative based on horizontal mutual aid.

Signs of success: (1) participating teams report reduced financial stress and increased capacity for long-term planning, (2) pool remains stable or grows over 12-18 months, (3) at least 2 other networks express interest in replication, (4) teams doing ecological work expand impact measurably.
